pages.text: A microcontroller is a black box, meaning you can't directly look at its internal state. However, sometimes you will want to take a look under the hood to fix bugs, or better understand your code better.$(br)Fortunately, there are a few ways to do this.$(li)One way is by add debug logic to your code,

such as by turning on specific pins or playing sounds at certain times. This has its advantages, but it also consumes runtime, so a slow microcontroller will run even slower.$(li)Another way is to use $(l:minecontrollers:microcontroller/pinout#special_pins)special pins$(). You can simply read values from specific memory cells, but this is likely the least effective way to debug your program
because you have to decode the output manually and you can't access register values.$(li)The most effective method is using the $(l:minecontrollers:microcontroller/debug#debugger_icon)debugger$().

The debugger lets you inspect your microcontroller and access all sorts of useful data. To start debugging, hold the debugger in your right hand and right-click the microcontroller. Doing so will display all register values and a small memory dump.
To set the start address of the memory dump, hold $(bold)[SHIFT]$() and scroll your mouse wheel.$(br)To switch scroll modes, press $(bold)RMB$() while holding $(bold)[SHIFT]$().
